description: From un- +‎ seat (“to provide with a place to sit”).

verbs.description: unseat (third-person singular simple present unseats, present participle unseating, simple past and past participle unseated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To remove or dislodge from a seat (especially referring to horse riding).
examples: The frightened horse reared up and unseated its rider.
I was unseated from my bike after hitting an unexpected pothole.

entries.meaning: To remove from some (especially political) position or office; to dethrone.
examples: After having lost her seat to a Tory, she succeeded in unseating him in the next general election.
India has recently unseated China as the world's most populous country.

entries.meaning: To cause something to be removed or replaced in its role; to displace, overturn.
examples: The Michelson-Morley experiment prompted scientists to unseat their belief in the luminiferous aether.
Printed newspapers are gradually being unseated by digital publications.

entries.meaning: To upset the composure of (in various ways); to astound, shock, or unsettle.
examples: Hyponyms: confound, vex, unnerve, disturb, discompose
The Matrix (1999) utterly unseated audiences around the world with its mind-blowing plot twist.
I was somewhat unseated by the strange noises outside my window.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, technical) To come out or off of a seat.
examples: We replaced the screws, since the old ones unseated too easily.
